description: Emerged primarily on the United States east coast in African American communities in the late 1970s; emphasizes rhythmic beat patterns and a type of spoken vocal delivery known as rapping.

subgenres.name: Abstract Hip Hop
subgenres.description: Uses much more abstract lyricism than what is considered conventional within the genre, typically through use of metaphors, symbolism, and cryptic meanings.

subgenres.name: Afroswing
subgenres.description: Emerged in the United Kingdom during the mid-2010s, incorporating influences from Dancehall, Afrobeats, Contemporary R&B, and a variety of West African Music.

subgenres.name: Afro Trap
subgenres.description: Centered mostly in France, features production influenced by modern styles developed in West and Central Africa with Trap-styled vocal flows.

subgenres.name: Arabesque Rap
subgenres.description: Emerged from Turkey in the late 2000s, based almost exclusively around Arabesk samples and featuring aggressive rap vocals.

subgenres.name: Bongo Flava
subgenres.description: Tanzanian genre originating in the mid-1990s in the Dar es Salaam area, combining the influence of Rhythm & Blues, Afrobeat, and Dancehall with native Tanzanian styles like Taarab and Muziki wa dansi.

subgenres.name: Boom Bap
subgenres.description: Production style identified by an acoustic-sounding drum pattern of a kick drum on the downbeat followed by a cracking snare on the upbeat.

subgenres.name: Bounce
subgenres.description: Developed in New Orleans in the early 1990s, initially defined by a slow to midtempo beat with a double-time hi-hat on top.

subgenres.name: Chipmunk Soul
subgenres.description: Sped-up vocal samples and slick soulful production.

subgenres.name: Chopped and Screwed
subgenres.description: Remixing technique pioneered by the late Houston producer DJ Screw in the 1990s, where tracks are slowed down and remixed with a skipping effect.

subgenres.name: Christian Hip Hop
subgenres.description: Employs lyrics with a pro-Christianity message to profess the performer's faith, and often to attract new attention from potential converts.

subgenres.name: Cloud Rap
subgenres.description: Emerged in the early 2010s, known for its relaxed, dream-like, and reverb-heavy production style, taking influence from Chillwave, and producers' obscure sample choices.

subgenres.name: Comedy Rap
subgenres.description: Primarily intended to be humorous, through the use of comedic lyrics, production, delivery, or other musical aspects.

subgenres.name: Conscious Hip Hop
subgenres.description: Artists whose lyrics deal with social issues.

subgenres.name: Country Rap
subgenres.description: Combines the flow, production-emphasis, and demeanor of Hip Hop with the lyrical content and general approach of Country.

subgenres.name: Crunk
subgenres.description: Originating from the southern United States and reliant on drum machines and synthesizer stabs to create an energetic, often dance-oriented sound.

subgenres.name: Drill
subgenres.description: Originated in Chicago in the early 2010s, broadly characterized by complex, energetic rhythms, coupled with street-conscious and often violent rapping.

subgenres.name: Emo Rap
subgenres.description: Moody, melancholic production combining atmospheric Cloud Rap, and Trap's typical drum programming, with sampling from Alternative Rock, Midwest Emo, Emo-Pop, and Pop Punk.

subgenres.name: Experimental Hip Hop
subgenres.description: Incorporates experimental and eccentric elements considered unconventional or unorthodox compared to more traditional hip hop.

subgenres.name: Industrial Hip Hop
subgenres.description: Incorporates harsh elements inspired by Industrial music such as blaring, noisy synths, distorted and metallic percussion, as well as more aggressive and off-kilter rapping styles.

subgenres.name: French Hip Hop
subgenres.description: Hip Hop originating from France, typically performed in the French language.

subgenres.name: Genge
subgenres.description: Combines elements of Dancehall with various traditions of Kenya.

subgenres.name: G-Funk
subgenres.description: Relaxed and organic sound featuring live instrumentation, use of P-Funk samples, and high-pitched synth lines.

subgenres.name: Hardcore Hip Hop
subgenres.description: Characterized by confrontation and aggression, whether in the lyricism, vocal delivery, hard beats, heavy production, or any combination thereof.

subgenres.name: Britcore
subgenres.description: British subgenre from the late 1980s and early 1990s featuring fast breakbeats and rapping.

subgenres.name: Gangsta Rap
subgenres.description: Lyrics from a gangster's perspective, typically within the Hardcore Hip Hop sound.

subgenres.name: Horrorcore
subgenres.description: Lyrical content and imagery focus on the macabre and morbid, including such topics as Satanism and suicide, with production generally of a darker nature than is typically found in other Hip Hop.

subgenres.name: Memphis Rap
subgenres.description: Characterized by minimalistic half-time drum machine programming with droning bass, often paired with aggressive rapping and a double time flow.

subgenres.name: Mid-School Hip Hop
subgenres.description: Based around heavy drum machine production sound.

subgenres.name: Trap Metal
subgenres.description: Features loud, distorted 808s and basslines, as well as aggressive vocals that are usually yelled or screamed.

subgenres.name: Hipco
subgenres.description: Developed in Liberia, often featuring conscious and political lyrics and influences from local dance styles.

subgenres.name: Hiplife
subgenres.description: Fusion of Ghanaian Highlife with Hip Hop.

subgenres.name: Hyphy
subgenres.description: Party-focused style with upbeat tempos, heavy bass and prominent synths, all underpinned by a distinctive West Coast-style rhythm, claps on beats 2 and 4, and a strong kick drum on beats 1, 2, and either 3 or 4.

subgenres.name: Instrumental Hip Hop
subgenres.description: Can take the form of instrumental versions of songs that normally feature rapping, or hip hop originally released and always intended to be instrumental.

subgenres.name: Japanese Hip Hop
subgenres.description: Hip Hop which is created by artists who are either based in or from Japan.

subgenres.name: Jazz Rap
subgenres.description: Incorporates elements of Jazz through the use of samples or live instrumentation.

subgenres.name: Jerk
subgenres.description: Sparse, snare-heavy drum patterns loosely inspired by Jerk Rap, which take major elements from other prominent 2010s and 2020s underground hip hop genres like Plugg.

subgenres.name: Jersey Club Rap
subgenres.description: Incorporates Jersey Club's distinct kick-heavy rhythms, which are modified to better suit rapping, featuring less sampling and more atmospheric production than earlier jersey club.

subgenres.name: Jersey Drill
subgenres.description: Mixes Drill and Jersey Club production, characterized by an energetic sound and distinct syncopated rhythms.

subgenres.name: Jigg
subgenres.description: Club-oriented genre characterized by heavy 808-driven beats, imposing synthesized brasses and an uptempo rhythm.

subgenres.name: Jook
subgenres.description: Fast-paced; draws influence from Bounce, Miami Bass, Jersey Club and Dancehall.

subgenres.name: Latin Rap
subgenres.description: Primarily done in Spanish; incorporates Hispanic American Music elements into its sound.

subgenres.name: Lo-Fi Hip Hop
subgenres.description: Relaxed, laid-back form of Hip Hop, typically instrumental and influenced by Jazz Rap and Downtempo.

subgenres.name: Lowend
subgenres.description: Rhythms driven by steady eighth-note digital handclaps, rattling bass, fast tempos, upbeat sound, and laid-back flows.

subgenres.name: Miami Bass
subgenres.description: Sustained Roland TR-808 kick drums and faster tempos, along with a distinct Electro influence.

subgenres.name: Mobb Music
subgenres.description: San Francisco Bay Area production style building on slowed down Funk (often utilizing live elements).

subgenres.name: Nerdcore Hip Hop
subgenres.description: Themes touch on such nerd mainstays as science, computers, and science fiction.

subgenres.name: Nervous Music
subgenres.description: Dark, sinister and menacing sound, heavy sub-basses, simple melodies and slow, sparse and slamming drums.

subgenres.name: Political Hip Hop
subgenres.description: Developed in the 1980s; features explicitly political lyrics and themes.

subgenres.name: Pop Rap
subgenres.description: Fuses Hip Hop's rapping and production traits with Pop elements such as melodious vocals and light, catchy tunes.

subgenres.name: Ratchet Music
subgenres.description: Club-oriented Hip Hop pioneered by Mustard defined by a repeated synth melody and a sparse drum pattern often accompanied by a 'hey' chant.

subgenres.name: Snap
subgenres.description: Prominent 808 bass and finger snaps, with lyrics primarily focused on nightclub topics (such as sex, drugs, and alcohol).

subgenres.name: Southern Hip Hop
subgenres.description: Hip Hop from artists based in the Southern region of the United States.

subgenres.name: Trap
subgenres.description: Originated in Atlanta in the early 2000s; distinctive fast hi-hat sound and heavy bass at moderate tempos.

subgenres.name: Detroit Trap
subgenres.description: Emerging in Michigan during the 2010s and incorporating upbeat 808 percussion derived from Trap music and dynamic, off-beat flows from rappers.

subgenres.name: Drill
subgenres.description: Originated in Chicago in the early 2010s, broadly characterized by complex, energetic rhythms, coupled with street-conscious and often violent rapping.

subgenres.name: Futuristic Swag
subgenres.description: Playful, Snap-influenced and party-oriented.

subgenres.name: New Jazz
subgenres.description: Colorful, repetitive synths and synthetic instruments, playful vocal chops, and wonky bass selections set to bouncy Trap drums.

subgenres.name: No Melody
subgenres.description: Usage of minimalistic, repetitive midtempo drum patterns, and simple, prominent 808s.

subgenres.name: Plugg
subgenres.description: Use of sparse and minimalistic drum and hi-hat patterns, subby 808s and heavy low end, piano samples, airy pads, and icy synths.

subgenres.name: Rage
subgenres.description: Dense, buzzing synth work with repetitive chord progressions and melodic synth leads.

subgenres.name: Rare Phonk
subgenres.description: Primarily features eclectic sampling and lush, jazzy beats, usually set to Trap rhythms with prominent influences of Memphis Rap.

subgenres.name: Regalia
subgenres.description: Lush, sweeping string arrangements, dreamy piano passages, and other orchestral instrumentation set to cinematic Trap percussion.

subgenres.name: Sigilkore
subgenres.description: Dark and hyperactive production, featuring rapping laced with layers of effects.

subgenres.name: Trap Latino
subgenres.description: Distinguished by its Reggaet√≥n and Latin Rap roots, with smooth and moody production inspired by Alternative R&B and Contemporary R&B.

subgenres.name: Trap Metal
subgenres.description: Features loud, distorted 808s and basslines, as well as aggressive vocals that are usually yelled or screamed.

subgenres.name: Trap Soul
subgenres.description: Mixes passionate vocals derived from Contemporary R&B with laid-back, nocturnal and atmospheric Trap production.

subgenres.name: Tread
subgenres.description: High-tempo production, usually set around 160 to 190 BPM, icy synths, busy drum programming with distinctive 808 patterns, often implementing off-beat hi-hats in addition to trap's triplets and a fast style of lethargic rapping.

subgenres.name: Turntablism
subgenres.description: Manipulating and re-appropriating vinyl records using a turntable and DJ mixer in a hip hop context, developing from production techniques in the studio and on the stage.

subgenres.name: UK Hip Hop
subgenres.description: Scene of the United Kingdom, influenced by American rap.

subgenres.name: West Coast Hip Hop
subgenres.description: Artists who originate from the West Coast region of the United States.
